item.label: Pons
item.name: Pons
item.description: The pons is that portion of the brainstem between the midbrain and medulla. It consists of a basilar or basal portion that contains structures primarily associated with motor control and a tegmental portion that contains cranial nerve nuclei and important sensory tracts. The cerebellum overlies the pons and medulla. The rostral aspect of the fourth ventricle is located on the dorsal surface of the pons. The pons and cerebellum originate embryologically from the metencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Cranial nerves of Pons
item.name: Nerves of Pons
item.description: The cranial nerves associated with the pons are the trigeminal (V), abducens (VI), facial (VII) and vestibulocochlear (VIII).  Note that the vestibular and cochlear nuclei are actually located in both the pons and medulla beneath the vestibular area --as seen in the floor of the fourth ventricle.  The vestibular and cochlear nerves enter the brainstem at the junction of the pons with the medulla in the cerebellopontine angle.

item.label: Trigeminal nerve
item.name: Trigeminal nerve
item.description: The fifth or trigeminal cranial nerve enters/exits the brain stem through the basilar portion of the pons. It provides somatosensory innervation to the head via its ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular roots which converge upon the trigeminal ganglion and then form a massive sensory root entering the brainstem. It provides motor innervation to the muscles derived from the first branchial arch (muscles of mastication, tensor tympani, anterior belly of diagastric, tensor veli palatini and mylohyoid) via a smaller motor root that distributes with the mandibular sensory root.

item.label: Motor root
item.name: Motor root
item.description: The trigeminal cranial nerve has both a sensory and motor root.  The motor root travels with the mandibular division of the sensory root.  The motor portion of the trigeminal innervates muscles derived from the first pharyngeal arch.  This includes the muscles of mastication, mylohyoid, anterior belly of the digastric, tensor tympani and tensor veli palatini.

item.label: Sensory root
item.name: Sensory root
item.description: The trigeminal cranial nerve has both a motor and sensory root.  The larger sensory root has ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular divisions that innervate the face and head.

item.label: Abducens nerve
item.name: Abducens nerve
item.description: The abducens nerve is the sixth cranial nerve.  It innervates the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle. It exits the brain stem anteriorly at the pontomedullary junction.

item.label: Facial nerve
item.name: Facial nerve
item.description: The facial or seventh cranial nerve has both sensory and motor components which enter/exit the brain stem in the cerebellopontine angle with the vestibulocochlear nerve. The most important sensory component carries taste from the anterior 2/3rds of the tongue; motor components innervate the skeletal muscles of facial expression, stapedius, etc. as well as provide the parasympathetic preganglionic fibers that control secretion of the submandibular, sublingual and lacrimal glands.

item.label: Vestibulocochlear nerve
item.name: Vestibulocochlear nerve
item.description: The vestibulocochlear nerve is AKA the statoacoustic nerve. This eighth cranial nerve enters the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle. It carries information from the hair cell receptors in the organ of Corti of the cochlear duct as well as from the vestibular organs (cristae of the semicircular ducts and maculae of the utricle and saccule of the inner ear).

item.label: Medulla
item.name: Medulla
item.description: The medulla is AKA the medulla oblongata. The most caudal aspect of the brain stem, it is located between the pons and spinal cord. It contains structures vital to survival such as cardiovascular and respiratory centers, as well as many cranial nerve nuclei. The major ascending and descending tracts travel through it between the spinal cord and higher centers. It originates developmentally from the myelencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Pyramid
item.name: Pyramid
item.description: The pyramid is a large fiber bundle located on the medial and ventral aspect of the medulla. It consists of corticospinal (and some corticobulbar) fibers that originate in the ipsilateral cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus and elsewhere). These upper motor neuron fibers terminate on lower motor neurons in the ventral horn of the spinal cord (corticospinal) and on cranial nerve motor neurons in the medulla (corticobulbar). Often referred to as the pyramidal tract.

item.label: Pyramidal decussation
item.name: Pyramidal decussation
item.description: The pyramidal decussation is where the corticospinal tract fibers that travel through the pyramid of the medulla, cross or decussate the midline of the neuraxis. This decussation marks the boundary between the medulla and spinal cord. As this tract travels in the spinal cord, it is known as the lateral corticospinal tract. Note that a few corticospinal fibers do not cross in this decussation and thus remain in a vental location in the spinal cord where they are known as the ventral corticospinal tract; these ventral corticospinal fibers generally descend only to cervical segments and will decussate in the ventral white commissure of the spinal cord before they synapse in the ventral horn.

item.label: Pre-olivary sulcus
item.name: Pre-olivary sulcus
item.description: On the ventral aspect of the medulla, the pre-olivary sulcus lies between the pyramid and the olive.  The rootlets of the hypoglossal cranial nerve exit the brainstem along this sulcus.

item.label: Olive
item.name: Olive
item.description: The olive is an oval-shaped bulge on the ventral lateral aspect of the medulla. The inferior olivary nucleus is located inside of this elevated area.

item.label: Post-olivary sulcus
item.name: Post-olivary sulcus
item.description: On the ventral-lateral aspect of the medulla, the post-olivary sulcus is located between the olive and the tuberculum cinereum.  The glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve branches enter/exit the brainstem in this sulcus.

item.label: Cranial nerves of Medulla
item.name: Nerves of Medulla
item.description: The cranial nerves associated with the medulla are the glossopharygeal (IX), vagus (X) and hypoglossal (XII).  Note that the vestibular and cochlear nuclei (VIII) are located in both the pons and medulla; as such they can be considered as part of the medulla as well.  The accessory nerve (XI) originates in the cervical spinal cord.

item.label: Glossopharyngeal nerve
item.name: Glossopharyngeal nerve
item.description: The ninth or glossopharyngeal cranial nerve has both sensory and motor components which enter/exit the brain stem along the lateral aspect of the medulla dorsal to the olive. The sensory component includes tactile sensation and taste from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue as well as input from the carotid body/sinus, middle and external ear; the motor component innervates the stylopharyngeus muscle (3rd pharyngeal arch origin) and provides the parasympathetic preganglionic fibers that control secretion of the parotid gland.

item.label: Vagus nerve
item.name: Vagus nerve
item.description: The tenth or vagus cranial nerve has both sensory and motor components which enter/exit the brain stem as a series of rootlets along the lateral aspect of the medulla dorsal to the olive and just caudal to the glossopharyngeal nerve. The most significant sensory component includes general sensation from the viscera, including input from the aortic body/sinus; the motor component innervates the laryngeal and pharyngeal muscles (4th and 6th pharyngeal arch origin) and provides the parasympathetic preganglionic fibers that innervate the thoracic and abdominal viscera.

item.label: Hypoglossal nerve
item.name: Hypoglossal nerve
item.description: The twelfth or hypoglossal cranial nerve is purely motor and innervates the ipsilateral intrinsic and extrinsic skeletal muscles of the tongue (except for the palatoglossus). It exits the medulla as a series of rootlets in the ventral lateral or anterolateral fissure between the olive and the pyramid in the medulla.

item.label: Cerebellum
item.name: Cerebellum
item.description: The cerebellum is sometimes referred to as the 'small' brain.  It is located within the posterior fossa, superior to the brain stem. It consists of a finely convoluted cortical surface of folia, a central core of white matter (AKA medullary center) and four paired deep nuclei (dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose) embedded within the white matter core. The cerebellum functions in the planning and coordination of movement.

item.label: Flocculi
item.name: Flocculus
item.description: The flocculus is the hemispheric portion of the flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum.  It is concerned with balance and equilibrium as well as movements of the eyes.

item.label: Posterolateral fissure
item.name: Posterolateral fissure
item.description: The posterolateral fissure of the cerebellum separates the posterior lobe from the flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum. It extends into both the vermal and hemispheric aspects of the cerebellum.

item.label: Middle cerebellar peduncles
item.name: Cerebellar peduncle (middle)
item.description: The middle cerebellar peduncle consists exclusively of pontocerebellar tract fibers that take their origin from pontine nuclei in the contralateral basilar pons. Thus, it carries afferent information to cerebellum from the contralateral cerebral cortex via the corticopontine to pontine nuclei to pontocerebellar tract.

item.label: Choroid plexus
item.name: Choroid plexus
item.description: The choroid plexus is the convoluted and highly vascularized structure in the ventricles that is responsible for the production of cerebrospinal fluid.  It is located in the floor of the lateral ventricle as it curves from the body of the ventricle into the inferior horn; it is not present in the anterior or posterior horns of the lateral ventricle.  From the lateral ventricle, the choroid plexus extends through the interventricular foramina of Monro onto the roof of the third ventricle.  In the fourth ventricle the choroid plexus extends downward from the inferior medullary velum that forms part of the roof the ventricle.  The choroid plexus also extends from the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka into the subarachnoid space.
